Description: Planet name most commonly used in the literature
Stellar name most commonly used in the literature
Number of stars in the planetary system
Number of confirmed planets in the planetary system
Method by which the planet was first identified
Year the planet was discovered
Name of facility of planet discovery observations
Time the planet takes to make a complete orbit around the host star or system (days)
The longest radius of an elliptic orbit, or, for exoplanets detected via gravitational microlensing or direct imaging, the projected separation in the plane of the sky
Length of a line segment from the center of the planet to its surface, measured in units of radius of the Earth
Amount of matter contained in the planet, measured in units of masses of the Earth
Amount by which the orbit of the planet deviates from a perfect circle

The equilibrium temperature of the planet as modeled by a black body heated only by its host star, or for directly imaged planets, the effective temperature of the planet required to match the measured luminosity if the planet were a black body
Classification of the star based on their spectral characteristics following the Morgan-Keenan system
Temperature of the star as modeled by a black body emitting the same total amount of electromagnetic radiation
Length of a line segment from the center of the star to its surface, measured in units of radius of the Sun
Amount of matter contained in the star, measured in units of masses of the Sun
Measurement of the metal content of the photosphere of the star as compared to the hydrogen content
Ratio for the Metallicity Value ([Fe/H] denotes iron abundance, [M/H] refers to a general metal content)
Gravitational acceleration experienced at the stellar surface
Right Ascension of the planetary system in sexagesimal format [log10(cm/s**2)]
Right Ascension of the planetary system in decimal degrees
Declination of the planetary system in sexagesimal notation
Declination of the planetary system in decimal degrees
Distance to the planetary system in units of parsecs
Brightness of the host star as measured using the V (Johnson) band in units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measured using the J (2MASS) band in units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measuring using the Gaia band in units of magnitudes. Objects matched to Gaia using the Hipparcos or 2MASS IDs provided in Gaia DR2
